The elevator doors ahead of Richard begin to close.

Welcome to my nightmare. The doors close as...
Margaret crosses the street and talks on the phone.

You've been thinking about our talk because I'm right.   Everyone does publicity.   Roth, McCourt, Russo.   Hell, Chabon practically whores himself.   Know what they have in common?   A Pulitzer. You've got a conference call in thirty, a staff meeting at nine, and your immigration lawyer sent some papers for you to sign.
Cancel the call, move the meeting to eight, (MORE)

Nice job.

As the message pops up on computers, the quiet office jum life as everyone in a cubicle picks up their phone and re their imaginary conversations.
Margaret comes out to Richard's desk.   She notices his c with Jillian's number on it.   She takes special notice o hearts that dot the "I's" in Jillian.
That's cute.   You gonna call her today?

Uh...

Margaret starts walking.   Richard quickly catches up, wo because he doesn't know where she's going with this.
I'm firing on all cylinders and you've got hearts on your coffee cup, wicked bed head, and a wrinkled suit that you wore yesterday.
Oh.   Well, it won't be wrinkled for long.
You'll magically unwrinkle?
Yes.

Does this work on more than just your pants?
Anything that's wrinkled.
Buy me some.
Will do. Richard makes a note.   Margaret stops to make her point.

I don't care what or who you do on your own time, but when you walk through that door you represent me, and I will not have your personal life affect you at work.   If you want me to think of promoting you to editor, I need you sharp, focused and professional. Got it?
Got it.
Great.   Now you're just a prop in here, so don't say a word. 8.

Margaret and Richard enter Bob's office, which is decorat beautiful antiques and first edition books.   But unlike Margaret's office, this one isn't in the corner. Margaret nods at Richard to shut the door.   BOB (42) wea bow tie, circular tortoise shell glasses, and the air of superiority.
Hey, Bob.
Ah.   Our fearless leader and her liege. Margaret smiles.

You're fired.

This isn't working out.
You can't...
I asked you repeatedly to get Frank to do publicity.   You said it was impossible.
It is.   He doesn't do publicity.
I just talked to him.   He's in.
But...
No more buts, Bob.   I've been chief for a month and a half, and this is the third time you've dropped the ball.   You didn't even call to ask him.

All you had to do to was pick up the phone. That's it.   Now I'll give you two months to find a new job, and then you can say you resigned.   I won't tell a soul, my lips are sealed. Margaret nods at Richard and he opens the door.
Margaret and Richard walk a few steps.   Margaret looks s ahead and whispers to Richard.
What's he doing? Richard turns around and takes a peek.   Bob gets out of and comes to his door.
He's up and about to pop.
Oh Bob, don't do it...
The office stops.   This is going to be good.   Margaret around with a disappointed look on her face.   She's dead
What are you doing?   I gave you a civilized way out of this.
This is because I'm your competition. Because I threaten you!

Oh, Bob.   You could never threaten me.   I'm firing you because you're lazy, entitled and incompetent.   I'm firing you because you don't work hard.   So if you know what's good for you, you'll shut up, take off that ridiculous bow tie, find a bar and get drunk.   Because if you say one more word, Richard here is going to call security and have you thrown out on your ass.   Are we perfectly clear? Bob nods. MARGARET (cont'd) Good.   Now I've got work to do, so if you'll 10. Margaret and Richard walk away and speak in hushed tones. MARGARET (cont'd) We need to call his authors and explain what happened.   And get Frank's publicity schedule figured out pronto.
No problem.   I'll just cancel my trip this weekend.
I gave you the weekend off?
It was my Grandma's ninetieth birthday. But no big deal.   You were right before, I need to stay focused.   Professional.
Richard is on the phone with his mom explaining why he ca home this weekend.   He sounds like an annoyed teenager.

Well tell gammy that I'm sorry. (waiting to speak) Mom, she's making me work this weekend. It's not like I volunteered. (waiting to speak) I'm sure dad is pissed. Margaret comes to Richard's desk.   He tries to wrap it u RICHARD (cont'd) I have to go.   Yeah.   No, I'm not going to do that!   No.   Sorta.   Mom!   No.   Bye. Richard hangs up the phone. RICHARD (cont'd) Sorry about that.   Damage control.
She tell you to quit?

No.   No. (off Margaret's look) Um.   Yes?   But as I've explained to them, after three years together, you're the only person on the planet who can make me editor, so that's the way it is. Richard's phone rings and he picks it up. 11. RICHARD (cont'd) Your 10:55 is here.   Mr. Gilbertson?
Who is this guy?
He said you knew each other.   You weren't sure so you told me to set a meeting.   We rescheduled on him four times.
Go get him.   But he's out of here in five minutes, we've got work to do. Margaret leaves and goes into her office.
(to himself) I'll charge up the cattle prod.
Margaret reads as MR. GILBERTSON (48) sits down.   He's a man in a bad suit.   He sits in silence until Margaret lo
Margaret.   Good to see you.   I know how busy you are.   Congrats on the promotion.   Read about it in P-W.

Yeah.   Well, those announcements are silly, aren't they?   Like everyone who needs to know doesn't know already. Margaret has been trying to figure out how she knows this but now gives up. MARGARET (cont'd) Have to admit, I can't place where we know each other from. Gilbertson smiles.   He didn't expect her to remember.
Three years ago?   We worked together.
Don't have it...
Remember "Dandelion's Desire?" Margaret gets excited. 12.
Oh my God, you read that manuscript with me? That book is legend.   Without a doubt the worst ever written.
You think?

It was a fever dream! pointless pages, with like 30 characters, who all had some weird disability.   The paraplegic pornographer, and the stuttering scientist?   Oh!   And there was the asthmatic alien chapter -- written entirely in his alien language.
I believe there was a glossary... Margaret laughs, caught up in the memory.
Did you see the pass letter I wrote him?
(QUOTING)

"Your grammar is impeccable, but please do not confuse superior form with writing ability.   Save your skills for the office newsletter, you sir, are no writer." A beat.   Margaret says matter of fact...
You wrote the book.
I did.
You're Dante Dickens?
One of my nom de plumes. Gilbertson paces.   Margaret stays seated, at a loss.

I'm sorry if I hurt your feelings.   You obviously were spending a lot of time writing, I just thought you should channel all that passion into something else. Gilbertson smiles as he pulls a BADGE from his coat pocke 13.
Ms. Mills, I'm with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, and I'm deporting you to Canada.
Excuse me?   What?   This is a mistake.   I've lived here since 1981.   I'm applying for citizenship.
You need citizenship now?   After the big promotion?
Yes.   And all the papers are in. Gilbertson pulls out a stack of papers and throws them do

Well, my office is going to reject your paperwork on Monday, while we investigate whether your behavior is well disposed to the good order and happiness of the United States.   We must protect our sovereignty.
I'm a threat to the sovereignty of the United States?

Yes, and unfortunately my investigation will take awhile, so you'll be deported while your case winds through the system. (as if he doesn't know) Will it affect you at work if you aren't allowed to enter the U.S. for the next two to three years?
"Affect me at work?"   I'll lose my job!
(mock sympathy) Ahhhh.   That's a shame.   Too bad we can't work something out. Margaret stops looking at her file.   It all becomes clea
Oh, no.   No, no, no.   I won't do it.
Do what, Ms. Mills?
Gilbertson smiles.   She's quick.
I've edited it down.   It's better.
Well then, get it published at another house.
They all just don't get me.
All?
Well not all.   Two hundred fifty, two hundred sixty-one.   Ish.
I'll be fired and laughed out of the industry if I publish that book.
I'm at the end of my rope, Ms. Mills.   I'm an author.   Not some bureaucrat who brings a lunchable to work everyday and lives in his brother's garage.   You're the last stop, and I'm desperate.
I will never publish your book.   Ever.
There's no need to make this difficult.   I don't turn in your file until Monday...
This is blackmail.   I'll go to your boss.

I've spent two years preparing for this day. Don't you think I've thought of that? Now Margaret is pacing, while Gilbertson happily looks on Suddenly, the door opens and Richard bursts in, acting li is an "emergency" so Margaret can end the meeting.
Excuse me, Ms. Mills, risk management needs you right away. The sight of Richard inspires Margaret.   She turns to Gi with a wicked grin on her face. 15.
Know what, Dante?   I'm not going anywhere! We're getting married! Richard has no idea what Margaret is talking about.

We are!
You and him?

You are marrying your male secretary?
Assistant.
You are marrying your male assistant?
(matter of fact) We're in love.   We tried to fight it.   When it's right, it's right.
And this has nothing to do with my visit here today?
Nope.   True love.   Got it bad.
(to Richard) You.   Is this true?   Are you marrying this... woman? Margaret comes over to Richard and holds his hand.
Of course we are.
Painfully long beat where Richard doesn't answer.   Marga squeezes Richard's hand hard.

Uh-huh. Margaret smiles and snuggles up to Richard so he can put around her.   Richard is truly afraid. RICHARD (cont'd) (more of a question) I'm, uh, marrying my boss? The two slowly begin to come to Just as their dry lips are about to touch, Richard chicke and kisses the hair on the top of her head.

Richard doesn't answer.   Margaret encourages him on with veiled threat.

Plum.

No.   Plum is "smokier" than purple. 17.
Favorite flower?
Tulips.   But only when they're in season.
Childhood pet name?
Miss Mittens.

(EXCITED)
My parents are dead!
How convenient.   So you're not telling anyone that you are getting married?
Nope. Gilbertson smiles and puts down his pad.
Pathetic.   Four questions and I've got enough to send you to prison...
We're telling his family this weekend.
We are?
Yes.   We are.   We're surprising them... (trying to remember) ...at his Grandma's 90th birthday party. 18.
And where's that going to be?
(no idea) At Richard's parent's house.

(still no idea) In his hometown.
Sitka.

Alaska.
You're going to Alaska this weekend?

Assistant.
...assistant to marry you and then conveniently telling his family for the first time this weekend?

Richard doesn't react.   Margaret doesn't notice. MARGARET (cont'd) So you need to figure out the travel, schedule a justice of the peace for next week, and get my lawyer on the phone. Margaret takes a sip of her coffee and makes a face. MARGARET (cont'd) But first, run down and get me another coffee from your girlfriend, this is cold. Margaret holds out her coffee cup.   Richard doesn't move MARGARET (cont'd) Hello?   Richard?   Richard! Richard says his first words since Gilbertson left.
I quit. Richard leaves Margaret's office.   She still has her cof outstretched in her hand. 20.

Richard, come back here. Margaret tries not to make a scene. MARGARET (cont'd) Richard.   Richard. Richard pushes the elevator button in front of reception. MARGARET (cont'd) Come back to the office! Richard can't take it.   He gets up in Margaret's face.

You want to talk with me?   Fine.   Grab your broom and let's go. Margaret is dumbstruck.   The receptionist is shocked. elevator arrives and Richard gets in.   Margaret follows. doors close, Richard shouts out to the receptionist. RICHARD (cont'd) Watch my phones!

Your plan is psychotic.
Well I'd rather poke my eyes out than play pretend girlfriend, but this is the big time.   Sometimes you need to sack up.

You wanna be an editor?   You need to make 21.
OK.   Fine.   Then if we "make this happen"? You're promoting me to editor.
I'm doing what?
We go to Alaska and lie to my family?   I risk going to jail?   Well, you're making me editor for that.   I mean, did you think I'd do this out of the kindness of my heart?
You work for me!
You know, during my employee orientation, the HR rep didn't mention anything about me marrying you.
Look, I came to this town alone and with nothing.   I've worked my ass off for fifteen years and this guy wants to ruin me because he wrote the shittiest book of all time?   No way.
Nice story Little Orphan Annie, but that sounds like your problem.   Not mine. Margaret is stuck.   Richard really does have the upper h

Fine.   You take me to Alaska this weekend, and I'll make you editor.   Deal? Margaret puts out her hand to shake, Richard takes it. MARGARET (cont'd) And I'm not sleeping on your parent's hide-a- bed, we're staying in a hotel.   Do they even have hotels in Alaska?
No.   But they have huts.   Teepees really. And you have to poop in a bucket.   But otherwise, just like the Four Seasons.   But with bears.

Richard and Margaret sit in First Class and work on their tops.   Richard looks up.
Um.   Shouldn't we talk about what we're going to say to my parents? Margaret doesn't look up, annoyed with the question.
Are you done with the press release?
Almost.
(PATRONIZING)
Well let's finish big people business before mommy and daddy talk.   Okay? Dejected, Richard goes back to work.

I told a em we've been dating for six months. We've kept it a secret from everyone... (under his breath) ...and that you're a naughty minx in the sack. Richard and Margaret make it to the attendant at the gate Margaret is not amused by Richard's attempt at humor.
(VENOMOUS)
Don't make me hate you. Margaret hands her boarding pass to the attendant and bre through.   The attendant gives Richard a look.

Bringing her home to meet my folks.   She's 23. Tangled in the bags, Richard struggles to find his boardi The impatient attendant is getting frustrated. RICHARD (cont'd) I've got it here.   Sorry.   Guess I'm a little flustered too.   Haven't been home for awhile, hope they like her! The gate attendant smiles.
(heard it all) I don't care, sir. Richard finds his boarding pass and hands it over.
OK then.   You're a sweet lady.   Thanks. Richard hustles to the plane as they shut the doors.
Margaret takes her seat and sits next to a well dressed H MAN who is READING A BOOK.   She notices the title and he her stare.   Margaret explains.
I'm sorry, I hate it when people stare at what I'm reading.   It's just... I worked on that book.
You wrote it?
Edited it.   It was one of my favorites.
Well you did a good job.   It's great.
You don't see many guys with that book. You, uh, read a lot of love stories about Roman concubines?
My ex-girlfriend gave it to me.   I travel a lot for work.   I'll read anything...
(SUSPICIOUS)
Ex-girlfriend, huh? 24.

(smiling, embarrassed) OK, you got me.   I'm a closet romantic.   But let's keep that between us. Margaret smiles and makes the "my lips are sealed" motion then, Richard lumbers onto the plane with the bags.
There you are.   Give me my lap top. Richard untangles the bags and gives Margaret her compute
(re: book) Hey, he's reading...
I know, Richard. Richard turns around and puts the bags in the overhead compartment.   The Handsome Man turns to Margaret.
Did you two want to sit together?
Sit together with who? The Handsome man nods at Richard.
Your boyfriend? Margaret points to Richard indignantly.
You mean him? The Handsome man nods.   Margaret tries to set the record straight. MARGARET (cont'd) No.   No.   No.   He's my assistant.
You're bringing your assistant all the way to Alaska? Richard smiles, happy that Margaret has to answer.
Oh, you can tell him the truth.

Well, he's... indispensable. 25. The Handsome man isn't buying it. MARGARET (cont'd) And gay.   Takes care of me everywhere I go. Call him my queen mother.   Aren't you my indispensable gay queen mother? Margaret shoots Richard a nasty look.   He has to go alon
That's me. Richard turns to close the overhead compartment.
You're awfully nice to fly him first class. Margaret nods her head and agrees.   It sucks to be Richa

We see the natural beauty of South Eastern Alaska.   Sitk island the size of Maui.   Only an eight mile stretch of inhabited, the rest is complete wilderness.   At the cent island is a mountain with smaller hills around it.   The dotted with fishing boats.   Gorgeous.
Margaret and the Handsome Man chat like old friends while walk off the plane.   Richard follows with all the bags. all walk out of the jetway they see...

A big banner that reads: CONGRATULATIONS RICHARD AND MARG with wedding bells and a graphic showing the journey from York to Sitka.   The banner is being held up by a group o PEOPLE with excited looks on their faces. Richard's mom DEBBIE (60) is front and center.   She's a lady who cooked Richard a hot breakfast every morning unt left the house. GRANDMA ANNIE (89) also waits.   She's lived a long time doesn't have a lot of time to screw around. When they see Richard, they SCREAM.   Margaret's face dro
There he is!!!   Where's Margaret? Richard blanches white.   Margaret looks back with eyes t "What the hell is going on?" 26.
(noting banner) That's sweet. Richard goes over to the group.   Margaret keeps walking.
What are you guys doing here?   What's with the sign?
So you're "just dating," huh?   I can't believe you didn't tell us!
Didn't tell you what?
We're not saying anything until you let us meet Margaret.   Now, where's our girl? Richard looks around.   Margaret keeps her head down and avoid eye contact.
Uh.   Margaret?   You need to come over here. Like now.   Honey. The Handsome Man sees Richard with the banner people, cal Margaret to come over.   Margaret winces.
I have to go now.
(putting it together) What kind of sick shit is this? Margaret nods.   This would be a tough one to explain.
Have a great life. Margaret walks toward the group.   Richard puts out his h silently pleads for Margaret to hold it.   At the last se takes it.
Everyone, this is Margaret.
It's nice to meet you.   Now, do you prefer being called Margaret, or the Dragon Lady? We've heard it both ways. Everyone laughs. 27.
Annnie!
It's not like he hasn't told her that he used to call her the Dragon Lady.   They're getting married.
(real "casual") Now, ah, where did you hear that?   The whole "getting married" thing?
Oh, that man from the government.   Gilber- something.   Said he was checking up on you two.   Said it was technicality, because Margaret was from Canada.
What, ah, did you tell him?
Well for one thing, that you were in a lot of trouble for not telling us that you two were getting married!
No.   Really.   What did you say?

Just that you were coming up here this weekend.   That we hadn't seen you in a while, and that we'd heard about Margaret for years, but that we'd never met her. Debbie turns to Margaret and takes both of her hands. DEBBIE (CONT'D (cont'd) The way that Richard talked about you?   I'll admit, I didn't see this coming.
Me neither. Debbie picks up some of the bags and starts walking towar exit.   Everyone else follows her lead.
So why all the silly secrecy?
It wasn't a secret.   We didn't tell anyone. 28.
Well, is your family just anyone?
No, I didn't mean...
I should be mad at you two.   But, but... I'm just so excited!
(re: group) Uh, is everyone coming to our hotel?
Oh, we cancelled your reservation.   You're part of the family now.     Family doesn't stay at a hotel.   Also, we've got another little surprise for you two.
Surprise?   Another surprise?
She's not good with surprises.
I'm really not good with surprises.
Debbie stops.   Sitka Airport is very small, so they are outside by all the cars parked in the loading zone. Debbie and Annie excitedly look at each other.
Well you two...
...you're getting married this weekend!
What? GRANDMA ANNIE (cont'd) The whole kit and caboodle. Margaret gives both these women a look that says "what ar talking about?"
When Gilber-something told us you were getting married...
...God rest their souls...
...or friends...
...we decided to give you a wedding.
Engagement party tonight...
...and the wedding tomorrow at midnight. Debbie and Annie wait to see what Margaret thinks.
Are you witches?
